John Ezra, Marshall Walthew and I are pleased to announce the winners and runners-up for the 2025 Griddies (f/k/a the Puzzle of the Year Awards):

Best Early Week Puzzle: Winner August 27 (Zhou Zhang), Runner-Up April 1 (Sande Milton)

Best Thursday Puzzle: Winner October 2 (Aidan Deshong); Runner-Up July 17 (Sam Brody)

Best Friday or Saturday Puzzle: Winner July 19 (Erik Agard); Runner-Up October 24 (Kelvin Zhou)

Best Sunday Puzzle: Winner July 6 ‚ÄúEscape Room‚Äù (Zhou Zhang and Kevin Curry); Runner-Up May 25 ‚ÄúTravel Bug‚Äù (Dylan Schiff)

Congratulations to all the winners and almost-winners!

Thanks to everyone who voted. And double thanks to everyone who had to re-enter their votes in the second round. 

Instead of repeating the ballot‚Äôs descriptions of the winning puzzles, John, Marshall and I have borrowed the words of the wonderful Wordplay columnists and puzzle constructors and editors (which, due to space limitations, will appear as replies to this comment).

[Messed up office space that‚Äôs difficult to put in order]



RUBIKSCUBICLE
Had a Natick with MIASMA/PILMICO, but was able to brute force it. Wednesday will mark 200 Days on my streak. Now, what do I do with the 8 hours until the Djokovic/Alcaraz Final...
There was no cheating with this puzzle, so there was no fudgsicle.

Hi can someone explain to me LYRICAL JET?

I understand the singing gang member from west side story.. I'm not getting the LYRJET bit when I take away the 'ical' sound.

Thanks!

I thought this was a clever conceit, but a few of the theme clues felt a bit off‚Äîas well as several other clues. NOT and NAUT and FALL and FOLL are hardly homophones. On the other hand I loved TWO PARTICLE HARMONY and BOSTONPOPSICLE and ‚Äúnews hound‚Äù was a very artful clue. As for other clues that put me off‚ÄîINMONO? You can say ‚Äúin stereo‚Äù so the extra IN is really odd there. It just doesn‚Äôt work. BLACKART‚Äîhas anyone ever said that not in a plural? Help me gamers‚ÄîLIFEBAR? Is that really a thing? I‚Äôve always called it a HEALTHBAR. AMNESIA for ‚Äúnever mind‚Äù? Just‚Ä¶off. There were a lot of sections especially the NW that seemed pretty ambiguous and/or Naticky and a bit forced. I don‚Äôt know what it was but I just didn‚Äôt have fun with this one even though the theme should be one I would enjoy. What did you all think?

The story of solving this puzzle?

CHRONICLEPAIN

Issues had trying to sort out this puzzles clues?

LOGICALJAM

Where a solver of this puzzle might be after it's completion?

CYNICALCITY

The theme was fine, but I did not enjoy the rest of the puzzle. Hard to put my finger on what exactly. The clues just felt bad.

Thanks to Eric Hougland and Marshall Walthew, we made the Griddies happen again this year and had good voter turnout and lots of good choices for the final round. See Eric's announcement of the winners in today's comments below (or above). 

And thanks to all of you here who voted! 

And remember to vote again in the future, here and also where you live. Democracy depends on those who vote.

For the first themer (23A), I added ICAL to CLASS CLOWN. Adding ICAL for the second themer (40A) didn't work; I needed to add ICLE to TWO PART HARMONY. For the third themer (65A) I not only had to add ICLE but I had to pretend FOLL was "fall" for the base phrase. The next two -- 88A and 94A -- also required phonetic changes after ICAL, and the last (113A), with ICLE, was a straightforward BOSTON POPS. There certainly was MUTATION in how the themers worked, as promised in the title, but I can't decide if that was fun or just a very loose theme set. Such are the mysteries of Sunday Crosswords.
My Diary of a Crossword Fiend review: https://crosswordfiend.com/2026/01/31/sunday-february-1-2026/#ny

It was sad to lose Jane Goodall last year, but my favorite primatologist (we all have one, right?) is Robert Sapolsky. I highly recommend all of his books, but I especially enjoyed his most recent, Determined: A Science of Life Without Free Will

(However, I listened to the audiobook and don't recommend that format; I plan to re"read" it on paper/e-book.)

I thought I'd take a break from flyspecking and come here to say how much I liked this puzzle.  Only a minor smattering of Oreos and plenty of fun clues to lighten my gloom about the Warriors' loss to the Pistons last night (so close! so close!). 

The theme made me think of a Pollyanna friend's sunny rejection of my favorite pastime:

"Never a Cross Word!"

You make a great team, John and Lance.  Thank you.  What's next?
A very challenging Sunday for those of us who aren‚Äôt sports inclined! Eventually got it without lookups, but BLEDSOE, NLMVP, the proper Bruins to get BOSTON POPSICLE‚Ä¶ouch!

[Crustacean that doesn't need oxygen to survive]



HERMETICAL CRAB

I figured out the ical/icle trick and solved the clues with answers that made sense. I never caught on that dropping the ical/icle sound yielded a common phrase.  My reaction: the juice wasn‚Äôt worth the squeeze.

After solving over 3,000 puzzles I feel like I‚Äôm starting to get the hang of this. Please don‚Äôt tell me the puzzles are getting easier. 

BTW, where‚Äôs Jim the crossword dog? Haven‚Äôt heard from him in a few days and want to make sure he‚Äôs ok.

Meh. A quick solve, but not fun. As someone who can't construct crosswords, I respect and admire the skill of putting them together. But the last time a Sunday puzzle was fun was the August 3 "Star Trek"-themed one; and I commented then how long it had been since I'd enjoyed a Sunday puzzle. Have I done so many that I've become jaded??? Add a few letters to a phrase, switch a few letters in a phrase ... the themes are becoming repetitive and boring.
Would love some extra clues today. While nonsensical to me I‚Äôve solved 100A without hint, I‚Äôm so stuck on some others.

Fun puzzle tho

BTW, speaking for myself only, please disregard some curmudgeons who feel entitled to demand every puzzle to be designed to match their taste. These crossword police don't allow trivia, rebuses, puns, or anything too esoteric. The puzzle must fit within exact specifications of difficulty level per relevant day of the week. Any violations will be met with derisive trolling. They'll even challenge fellow crossword solvers who post a positive comment, and taunt such lack of malice as 'mollycoddling.'

Lacking EQ, they jump at the chance to spend 1 minute trashing something that others took days to build and are proud of. And which at least some others in the crossword community appreciated. 

Dear crossword creators, I appreciated your puzzle and look forward to more from you as partners in cluing and your solo puzzles as well. Cheers!

Thanking the setters and editors. I would say A for effort. The rest was ü´§

I just wish I was as clever as other commenters who add their own takes on the theme, but I'm stuck.  Test result? No. Test tube? Uh, no. Test harness?!?

Top 10 WW2-era movies?


SCHINDLER‚ÄôS LISTICLE

Well, I‚Äôm a fan of silly, when it's good.  

And today, to me, it was. First of all, ‚Äúickle‚Äù is funny sounding. That helps. Then, when you add it to a word and substitute it for the original word in a common phrase, that‚Äôs prime wordplay, and today it hit my happy button.

The two constructors, per their notes, brainstormed hundreds of possibilities before landing on today‚Äôs seven.  That not only shows remarkable perseverance, but also that they worked hard on making this puzzle the best it can be.  

So, add inspiration and respect to my smiles.  Extra points for the lovely shorts GRIST and MIASMA.

Regular NYT solvers will know John well from his seven puzzles last year alone.  Lance, with three puzzles in four years, maybe not so readily, but let me remind you of his wit from two of his past clues: [Competition that begins and ends with a tie], and [Material for a lighter wheel].  (Answers in a reply).  

Thank you, John and Lance.  This was splendid!
Slowly but surely‚Ä¶

That was tough, until it wasn‚Äôt. A good Sunday workout with a cute theme.  I caught on with WE‚ÄôRE NAUTICAL WORTHY. Don‚Äôt really understand BOSTON POPSICLE but I guess it‚Äôs a sports reference.
Trouble is 94A has stung me with Hotstepper as the ear worm of the day, ‚ÄòI‚Äôm the LYRICAL gangster‚Äô. I‚Äôm going to have to go through the whole song now to get it out of my head.

I'm with the band on this one.

By coincidence, [Orbit(al)] = EYESOCKET was the subject of a Jeopardy question this past week. According to Cousin Ken, that usage predates the astronomical one.

I wondered why [tech] wasn't capitalized. Then I found out that the California Institute of Technology brands itself as "Caltech," one word. Wait, educational institutions need branding?

THEA, usually spelled Theia, is just an adjective meaning "divine," which she probably used as an epithet, like Scary, Posh, or Sporty, in place of a birth-name she found embarrassing. She's one of the Titans, and the Titans, apart from Kronos, were a pretty boring lot, basically just there to fill up genealogical lists.

Early on, I was trying to solve [Pale lager, informally], and I already had PI_S on the grid. One candidate letter immediately came to mind, but I was fairly confident that the Grey Lady would never allow that as an answer, so I waited for the cross. PILS made immediate sense when I got it, since I‚Äôve actually been to Plz≈à, Czechia, though I‚Äôm not sure I‚Äôve heard that abbreviated form for the beer often, if ever, before (having spent the vast majority of my time on earth while of legal drinking age in non-English-speaking countries). I can assure you that the pilsners actually from Plz≈à would never be described as my initial hunch!

If the theme were something outstanding then this might be OK. But here, well the theme seems rather pedestrian ... and it doesn't really work. "FOLL" is not "FALL", and they don't sound the same. And "NAUT" isn't "NOT", and they're also not homophones---at least to me.

Solved it without assistance or errors in about 40 minutes. Liked some of the entries, especially the vowel-free NLMVPS and the uncommon words MIASMA and MYOPE.

But overall ... well, I hope others actually enjoyed this one.

LYRICAL JET was especially clever (perhaps because I was thinking that it would have to be musICAL), and CLASSICAL CLOWN was very nice, the last of the themers to fall for me, allowing a pleasant ending to the puzzle. Of course, FOLLICLE was a bit of a reach, and so was NAUTICAL, but the latter was worth it, if only to hear Wayne and Garth in one's head: "WE'RE NAUT WORTHY!!!" https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jjaqrPpdQYc And there's Mike MYERS, hiding in the SouthEast!

VISAVISAVISA "Grandpa Simpson, describe a Genesis figure"? ABELABELABEL "Jockey who's jeered by me?" RIDERIDERIDE "Detective catches sight of baker wares?" PIESPIESPIES Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=5/20/2015 ....

Whoever came up with that bad idea is in the same league as those who put wood dust in some breads to cut down on calories.

I'm surprised by the mixed reactions today as I thought the puzzle was superb both in theme and execution. No trouble here with any of the homophones, and BOSTON POPSICLE was one of my all-time favourites! I haven't seen any mention of the fact that by applying the theme to the puzzle's title one is left with "Commutation".

I finished last night and had an error. It ended up being mLMVPS/CASHIm. I was thinking major league vs National League üò¨ Anyhoo, one error isn‚Äôt too bad on a Sunday for me. I was so tired by the time I finished and fly specked that I only got on here and thanked Eric, John and Marshall for all of their efforts on bringing us the Griddies. Thanks again, guys! And thank you to Lance and John for contributing to my daily routine of solving. It‚Äôs kind of ironic that my husband is from Boston and now works for UCLA üòâ BLEDSOE was an instant gimme as well as my husband is a huge Patriots fan. Happy February, everyone!‚ù£Ô∏è

This theme was poorly executed. 

First there is CLASSICALCLOWN, adding 'ical' to the common phrase 'class clown', with a similar addition to 'top dog' making TOPICALDOG. Nice start. But then the theme entries include homophones (LYR/lear) and alternate spellings as in ...POPSICLE. 

Very sloppy. 2/10.

Caught on to the theme pretty quickly but then had to figure out the variations on the theme, which added continuing interest during the solve. I thought my favorite was going to be the one about particle physics, but then reached the nod to Wayne's World. That one rated a bow.

This was not too hard, but chewy enough to occupy a little more time than usual, which I very much appreciated.

Meanwhile, I got distracted by the constructor notes and fell down one splendid rabbit hole. Aieee! I do not need another distraction! And I haven't gotten around to reading the POY winners. Almost missed those.

Not a very satisfying theme in my opinion. I could get over there not being a theme revealer in the puzzle. I'm okay with "ical" being spelled differently, even though it's a little bit of a reach, it's okay. But when you also throw in the homophones needing to be used at the beginning of the phrases for them to make sense, along with all the rest, I feel like it's too much of a reach to be considered a consolidated theme puzzle. Reaching as far as the freaking moon. Leave it themeless next time <3
Could not catch the constructors wave. Had a few aha!moments but struggled. I admire the brilliance of the grid though. Looking forward to easy Monday so I feel less ignorant.
Oh my god.  Messing up on the big screen.  I HATE YOU!  (lololol). That was a lot of fun!
Very fun! Thank you, guys, for a clever whimsICAL Sunday puzzle!
Second time in a week that my optometry background has come in handy for something other than giving people facts about ‚Äúpink eye‚Äù!

Took me a while, with the help of several look-ups, but finally got it done.  Solved it pretty much from the bottom to top.  The Northwest section had me flummoxed until things started to fall in place.  Had a few typos in there which did not help my cause - hitting the keys a bit too fast.  Good puzzle.

This was kind of wild in that I absolutely raced through the puzzle, and really enjoyed it... but absolutely did not connect the dots on the theme until reading the column here! The theme answers were a little out of the language, but I honestly just thought it was one of those things where I'm not on the constructors' wavelength. Turns out, I was entirely on their wavelength to the extent that I could miss the joke and still get what they were saying.

I had BOSTON teaSICLE for a while, which was a fun response that seemed to fit with the themeless puns. I do wonder if there is some modern metaphorical tea we could throw in a harbor to complement the ICE out protests.

Absolutely phenomenal puzzle! I was able to pick up on the fun gimmick of the theme early, and that let me place the "ical/icle" segments relatively quickly, but while I grasped the theme, it took far longer than I'd like to admit to finally wrap my fingers around a couple of the full answers, particularly that one about electrolysis. But it was wonderfully satisfying when each one finally clicked, and the only thing I had to look up was that last Spice Girl and keg size.

p.s. "Messing up on the big screen" was a brilliantly evil clue, I loved it!

Theme was clever but didn't like the phonetic tricks needed to make some work. Hard enough with North American proper nouns, an even higher barrier to need the accent to make the solves make sense. A few too many trivia on top. Not the worst, not the best.

Speaking only for myself, the best Sunday puzzles are ones where the clues aren‚Äôt too tricky. I mean, there are a LOT of them. I don‚Äôt like to work too hard on the ‚Äúday of rest‚Äù. But that‚Äôs just me. The puzzle was impressive, but not my favorite for a Sunday.
I can only imagine how many hours it took to cuticle and polish  (messy manicurist?) this gem of a puzzle. Super clever. Loved it.
Before I got it, I actually googled "daerbana fruit loaf".

What ‚ÄúOK Boomer‚Äù means to me:

Is that term really a putdown? HA! When I've heard the term ‚ÄúOK Boomer‚Äù in the workplace, it usually came from the GenYers (millennials). The blurry lines between Ys and Zs are inconsequential to me, but I love them all. After all, we baby boomers produced the Millennial Generation. They‚Äôre all young up and coming, and are establishing a foothold, just like we did.

I've observed that the biggest critics of the Millennials came from the GenXers, not us. They were relentless in the  pursuit of ‚Äúkeeping them in their place,‚Äù and I applaud that.
Thusly, when I hear that term, I‚Äôm far from put down. Instead, I hear the following implications from that work of oratory genius:

- I have no creativity
- I have no originality
- I just go with the whatever (TikTok, etc) trends dictate
- I am entitled
- Life started with me

We boomers, according to my research, indicates that we have accumulated the largest amount of wealth (through hard work and investing) than any other generation in the history of this great country.

Do I think you Y and Z‚Äôs are worthy of reaping the benefits of the investing and saving that my 50+ years of hard work and sacrifice has produced? H-E double hockey sticks no! Am I spending my kids‚Äô inheritance? Yes, the heck I am!
So, create your own legacy, as we boomers did. The terms "so lame" "yeet" and "OK Boomer" shouldn't be "your thing."


‚Äî- I hope no feelings were harmed during this rant ‚Äî-

One more late puzzle find. By far the most unusual I've ever encountered. A Sunday from December 15, 1996 by Randolph Ross with the title: "Bumper to Bumper." A triple stack of 21 letter theme answers across the middle. All with the same clue: "Traffic Jam" Those answers: FIREENGINECARRACERRIG TRAMROADSTERMOTORHOME SEMIVANAUTOSEDANMOPED And that stack was crossed by three 21 letter down answers with the same clue. The cross of LIFEBAR with ESSIE is what they used to call a ‚ÄúNatick,‚Äù but times (and puzzles) have clearly changed. I plod on with my meager store of trivia and proper nouns, and today was happy to finish just a few squares shy of clean solve. It was a fun workout, but I still found this puzzle a little disappointing. The wordplay in the theme entries ought to deliver a kick, but today‚Äôs punning was too strained to be effective; when I finally figured out the trick, I felt  nothing more than a playful tap on the shoulder. For me, dialect was a big issue, and it seems other bloggers had a similar reaction. If you don‚Äôt pronounce the same first vowel in LYRICAL as in ‚ÄúLear(JET)‚Äù, in NAUTICAL as in ‚Äúnote,‚Äù or in FOLLICLE as in ‚Äúfall,‚Äù it blunts the edge. A good puzzle should be dialect-neutral.

One more late puzzle find. Never seen another like this either. I think it is unusually clever. A Tuesday from October 21, 2008 by Randall J. Hartman. Five 15 letter theme answers starting at row 3 and then evenly spaced from top to bottom. Clues and answers in order: "P" - SIXTEENTHLETTER "PO" - RIVEROFLOMBARDY "POL" - CAPITOLHILLTYPE "POLK" - FORMERPRESIDENT "POLKA" - OKTOBERFESTTUNE Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=10/21/2008&g=55&d=A .....

Sorry, but is there something more to the theme than simply removing the sound "ICAL' from the entries?

Not the greatest theme. A few of them were a REAL stretch and were not satisfying to solve.

For me, this was the worst ever Sunday puzzle over the past 2 years I have been playing. Diabolical theme with homophones, too niche trivia, poor clues, unsolvable crosses, and so on. This puzzle shouldn't have passed the editor's desk.

Other commenters have mentioned about other poor clues. I will take my grudge out on [Not Stereo] which should ideally solve to MONO, but it solves to IN MONO. With so much of trivia already in the puzzle, I didn't appreciate how simple words like SIR were also clued niche trivia.

The puzzle seemed forced and not at all a happy fill.
In addition to everyone‚Äôs comments above, I was also disappointed with 78A solving to MEN. The use of W.C. implies an abbreviated answer.

I found the theme to be a bit more obscuring than illuminating, with the payoff of de-icle-ing a phrase not always worth the mental energy.

Combined with a fill full of names and arcana usually reserved for a stunt puzzle, it made this a bit of a slog for me.

This one reminded me of the Pig Latin puzzle last year (spoiler: August 17), which phonetically contorted phrases to the point where my enjoyment peaked at begrudging recognition.

I‚Äôm personally finding phonetic mutations most enjoyable with particularly clever cluing (like if they were all like TWOPARTICLEHARMONY) or if there is a uniting categorical theme in addition to the mutation. Otherwise it seems a bit frivolous.

Just started up with the puzzles after a few decades of layoff and was able to solve it with one lookup (4 down nail polish maker).  Maybe I'm just not jaded enough yet, but was surprised by the number of disparaging remarks, perhaps it's a case of winter wrapper....Vanilla Icicle?

I thought the theme was clever, and the clues were plenty sufficiently puzzling for Sunday.   I had to come to the column to get how ICAL  was related to the title hint of the puzzle (duh).  And the Constructors' note gave me a  good laugh, to make up for my longish solve time!

Oof. That NE corner was an absolute slog. I enjoyed the rest of the grid, but that whole area felt like repentance for some nondescript sin I may have committed this morning. PIMLICO/OPIE crossing with BLEDSOE was a torturous density of proper names I had to fill with guesses, and I really don‚Äôt enjoy clues as painfully generic as ‚Äúsome school subject‚Äù and ‚Äúsome Atlantic fish.‚Äù 

It contrasted rather sharply with the rest of the puzzle, which had some delightful, original clues, like those for NINJA, AMNESIA, SERIF, and SEXTOYS. 

One of the more challenging Sundays in the last few months, no doubt. I just wish proper names and utterly vague clues didn‚Äôt make up such a big part of this challenge.

@Eric Hougland

Best Early Week Puzzle

Winner August 27 (Zhou Zhang) ‚Äî A next-level Schr√∂dinger puzzle. ‚ÄúIn a Schr√∂dinger puzzle, each theme entry can have two possible correct answers in the same slot that differ by one or more letters, and the crossing answers work with either entry.‚Äù (Deb Amlen). Zhang notes on xwordinfo: ‚ÄúThis puzzle has a very special place in my heart because it's the first one I had accepted by the New York Times. Looking back on it, I'm honestly shocked I even got it to work. Unusual grid size ‚Ä¶ a lot of theme material ‚Ä¶ plus a¬†Schr√∂dinger‚Ä¶rebus??? This is clearly the hubris of somebody who has no idea what they're getting themselves into, and I say that with only love and affection to my former self.‚Äù

Runner-Up April 1 (Sande Milton) ‚ÄîUnique puzzle with the revealer IN-FLIGHT MAGAZINE explaining why some of the squares have been filled in (sometimes wrongly!). As Sam Corbin wrote, ‚ÄúI encourage you to think of these less as mistakes than as points of departure. They add to the satisfaction you‚Äôll feel when Mr. Milton‚Äôs brilliant joke finally lands.‚Äù Corbin also wrote, ‚ÄúI found the real brilliance of the theme to be its red herrings. The right answer to 17A‚Äôs [Declare openly] is AVOW ‚Äî but ‚Äúaver‚Äù could have been right. [Genetic material] at (41A) is DNA here, but the clue could just as easily have solved to RNA.‚Äù

@Eric Hougland

Best Thursday Puzzle

Winner October 2 (Aidan Deshong) ‚ÄîA MINESWEEPER themed puzzle. Deb Amlen: ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think I am overstating things when I say that this grid is brilliant. It‚Äôs a rebus, which is a reasonable thing to expect on a Thursday: The word MINE or the first letter, M, needs to be entered into six of the puzzle‚Äôs squares. The rebus works for both the Across and Down answers. For example, the answer to the clue at 17A, [How something distinctive appears] is PRO(MINE)NTLY, and the crossing answer to the clue [AD ___] at 4D is HO(MINE)M.‚Äù AND the grid also works as a real MINESWEEPER game.¬† ‚ÄúThe numbers indicate how many bombs they are adjacent to,‚Äù puzzle editor Christina Iverson said. ‚ÄúSo the two means that square is touching two bombs.‚Äù

Runner-Up July 17 (Sam Brody) ‚ÄîA MATRYOSHKA DOLL themed puzzle, the famous Russian nesting dolls. In this case, the parentheses ‚Äúnest‚Äù clues inside each other, and the same is true with the answers (such as (TI(ME(MACH)IN)ES), or TIME MACHINES). Deb Amlen: ‚ÄúDid your brain, like my own, immediately shut down as soon as you opened Sam Brody‚Äôs puzzle? How about your heart? Did it pound as you tried to figure out what was up with all the parentheses in the clues?‚Äù But as she concluded, ‚ÄúAs strange as the clues look, they are admirably consistent, or what constructors call a ‚Äòtight‚Äô theme set. As a whole, today‚Äôs puzzle is a great demonstration of how constructors think: They tend to notice patterns in language.‚Äù

@Eric Hougland

Best Friday or Saturday Puzzle

Winner July 19 (Erik Agard) ‚Äî[A] beautiful grid with a low word count and lots of long interesting fill. Its showpiece is the quadruple stack of full-length entries in its center. It looks like a beast to solve, and indeed there are many areas where a solver needs tenacity and mental flexibility to move forward, but it‚Äôs very fair. ‚Ä¶ I think this puzzle is great for anyone who rises to the challenge ‚Äî a puzzle that‚Äôs intimidating but doable and that makes you feel accomplished in the end.  ‚Ä¶[I]t‚Äôs high art for a constructor to be able to combine so many imposing elements into a harmonious solve. (Caitlin Lovinger)

Runner-Up October 24 (Kelvin Zhou) ‚Äî[Mr. Zhou‚Äôs] grid is quite good. [It] even introduces us to seven debut entries. The solving just required a substantial tug of war between my brain and Mr.Zhou‚Äôs. ‚Ä¶ The experience perfectly demonstrates what I like to think of as the cruciverbal version of a popular idiom: some days you get the puzzle, and some days the puzzle gets you. ‚Ä¶ There‚Äôs some greatness in Mr. Zhou‚Äôs puzzle and you won‚Äôt want to miss it. (Deb Amlen)

@Eric Hougland

Congratulations to all the winners‚ÄîZhou Zhang winning two, that‚Äôs quite a feat! Champagne in the Curry/Zhang household tonight. I‚Äôm pleased and a bit surprised at the Escape Room win, because it was quite polarizing at the time, if I recall. It just goes to show that it‚Äôs worth going out in a limb and stretching boundaries even though some people won‚Äôt like it, you may astonish others. I‚Äôm reminded of a lyric from the little known musical [title of show]‚Äîyes, that‚Äôs really the title‚Äî‚ÄúI‚Äôd rather be nine people‚Äôs favorite thing then a hundred people‚Äôs ninth favorite thing.‚Äù Congrats again!
Thanks, gang!

@Eric Hougland

Winner July 6 ‚ÄúEscape Room‚Äù (Zhou Zhang and Kevin Curry) ‚Äî

"[T]hough everything that you need to solve this puzzle is here, I think its final steps will have many solvers climbing the walls. ‚Ä¶ If you are at the point where you‚Äôve solved everything in the grid except for [the isolated word at] 69-Down and are stumped, here‚Äôs a hint: Each theme entry hints at another entry in the puzzle, which furnishes the missing information. ‚Ä¶[T]he whole process to determine the final key is quite a challenge. I won‚Äôt be surprised if some solvers guess the word and reverse engineer each letter." (Caitlin Lovinger)

Runner-Up May 25 ‚ÄúTravel Bug‚Äù (Dylan Schiff) ‚Äî"This is a wicked puzzle from Mr. Schiff, whose last Sunday puzzle included an inventive series of jokes about the digital era. Today‚Äôs grid goes beyond the digital, to an intergalactic degree. ‚Ä¶ In order to see [the theme], it‚Äôs important to register the six circles [in the grid] as three pairs. One pair is blue .‚Ä¶ One is pink ‚Ä¶. And one pair is yellow, .‚Ä¶ Each color ‚Äî blue, pink and yellow ‚Äî has a different rebus element, which therefore appears twice in the grid. ‚Ä¶ [The rebus] BOOK goes in the pink circles, as the fulcrum where each of these entries moves to its corresponding spot in the grid. Why BOOK? I only understood once I‚Äôd filled in 69-Across, partly by deduction, mostly from the crossing entries. It solves to WORMHOLE." (Caitlin Lovinger)

@JohnWM

You have to know which are the relevant sounds to click on.

People around here, and I think most of North America, pronounce "fall" with the vowel sound …î, and "foll(icle)" with the vowel sound √§.  Click on the sound file for both to hear the difference.

Same with "naut(ical)" and "not."

Steve L,

Thanks. I clicked and listened, and found it less than helpful. I think because to me, the dis-embodied and dis-en-worded sounds seem dissimilar to how we actually say words. I think I would say I say (and usually hear) both as something closer to the √§ sound.

When I Google ‚Äúpronounce fall‚Äù and ‚Äúpronounce follicle‚Äù and listen, the opening vowels of the words sound identical to me. But again, I don‚Äôt feel helped, because that is just one pronunciation of each - and maybe not even representative of most of North America (?).

As for knowing which symbol to click: no, I don‚Äôt have to know - and that is my point about those tables of symbols. Only professionals or very motivated enthusiasts will memorize and/or correctly understand them. I can read English, and I can hear (for both, at least reasonably well). It would be nice (though hard to arrange) to have online dictionaries provide and identify various pronunciations, even ‚Äúrare‚Äù or ‚Äúalternate‚Äù or ‚Äúobsolete‚Äù ones.
